‚ÄúWasting time‚Äù on mindless activities can actually help your brain thrive. 

What do you do during your downtime to recharge your creativity?
Learn more about being a productive time-waster in our new TED Book, In Praise of Wasting Time, by Alan Lightman: https://t.co/xsI3HOez2O https://t.co/EeY8RKlfG9

‚ÄúDowntime is when we can ponder our past and imagine our future. ‚ÄòWasting time‚Äô is far from immoral uselessness. It may be the most important occupation of our minds,‚Äù says scientist and @TEDBooks author Alan Lightman.

Gertrude Stein took writing breaks to wander the countryside looking at cows. Gustav Mahler went on three-hour walks after lunch, stopping to jot down ideas in his notebook. Federico Fellini would wake up at 6am to walk about the house, open windows, and move books around.

Taking time to mediate allows you to follow your thoughts in an unhurried way and weave a narrative of who you are and what you believe in. It‚Äôs worth taking time to distance yourself from the rush of the world.
Simply letting your mind wander and embracing free-floating thoughts lights up different parts of your brain and could inspire creativity.

Does planning every second of your day make you less creative? 

Scientist and @TEDBooks author Alan Lightman makes the case for doing nothing more often as a way to refresh your mind. Here‚Äôs why you should prioritize some downtime.
By not giving ourselves the minutes ‚Äî or hours ‚Äî free of devices and distractions, we risk losing our ability to know who we are and what‚Äôs important to us. https://t.co/I5NVvgDzvJ
